content: If there are no objections, I would like to add cover art to this puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I enjoyed solving this puzzle especially because there were not additional pitfalls while solving a realistic task.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle, hopefully CG will fix the OCaml stub generator.
I tested the generated stubs and OCaml has an issue with the starting code : exception End_of_file.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Approved, fun puzzle

Seems like a toned down version of 'Fun with Set Theory'. All the spaces are okay i guess.  Recursion isn't really a requirement.  Can be solved a bunch of different ways.  Your solution, in my opinion, is not exactly optimal...but I'm not doing much java these days.  Looks ok as is, props for that.
I just played the latest version and really enjoyed it, great puzzle! My C++ solution used recursion to handle [ and ( sub terms :-)

I note that all your resistor names are single uppercase letters, if this is intentional then perhaps the puzzle could reflect this some way (e.g. redefine name as word(1)), if not then perhaps some variety would be nice.
Your statement looks fantastic,  great visuals and example, one small tweak could be the text under "Example:" which may benefit from monospace. Also perhaps add emphasis: <<Example:>>

Your stub script looks fine, however I do note that the documentation says "A loopline will collect <amount> times repeated data from a single line", whereas your usage is for multiple lines. Maybe try "loop" instead of "loopline" to see if it generates the correct result also.
I think in your statement when you say "A resistance" you may have meant "A resistor"

Have you seen this puzzle https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/53596adfab1e911132d74e0ca17640d0f5c1
The difference is that here we sum numbers instead of handling booleans. But you said it yourself in the previous post : the main challenge is to create a parsing algorithm, and in this case both puzzles are very close.
Edit : actually yours introduces recursive parsing compared to the other one, but I'm not sure this would be enough to differentiate them.

Let me know if you think this should be medium. 

** SOLUTION APPROACH SPOILERS WARNING BEYOND THIS POINT **

I significantly toned down the difficulty of the problem because I realized that the point isn't to manage long processes but rather to create a parsing method and algorithm (perhaps including one to handle fractions rather than storing decimal values depending on your approach).

I really tried to make this as simple as possible since I've been struggling with keeping my puzzles brief in terms of the statement as well as with the complexity of my test cases/validators. Hopefully this puzzle is a more manageable read/solve.

I was the first to approve that puzzle and I feel this is quite difference because this puzzle actually utilizes parse theory while the other only requires parse storing of input strings. Also figuring out how to approach the order of parse resolutions is different. The idea of parallel and series switches is the same simply because it is a physical property of electrical circuits. His puzzle is good but also quite different.
corrected
this was really great feedback thank you. I've updated it and I agree its much more aesthetically and format-wise appealling.
good idea. that should help further the division of sections of the statement.

both you and djoums suggested recursion to handle terms, should I add it to the tags? I didnt use recursion, I just simplified the inner terms first and went outwards until all the arrangements were simplified to one value.
i agree that recursion is not a requirement. I wasn't really going for an optimal code, I just wrote it the way I would have approached it.
I’m appreciative of your involvement  :)
I’ll check it out in the next dozen hours or so

https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/community-puzzle-dungeons-and-maps/185975/2

Very thorough of you! This is a known issue. I found that the problem can be resolved by using a single command loop to read the "resistor" lines instead of separately reading the "name" and "resistance" BUT I do not want to do this because it is not helpful in the stub and a OCaml user will encounter this issue every puzzle they do. I will make a report or forum post about my findings.
https://forum.codingame.com/t/contribution-stub-generator-input-error/186326/15?u=schwase

I read the posts and I agree it seems like an issue for CG to fix, not you.

Edit : it takes 2 minutes to test all the stubs, that's something worth doing once the puzzle is ready imo.

also I don't think this puzzle is anything like fun with set theory except that this requires parsing. The input in this puzzle is not implied and does not involve unions and junctions like that puzzle. This puzzle requires algorithmic use of numericals to find a single answer. Is your impression based on your first impression or based on your experience doing the puzzle?
I didn't do it yet, I'll wait til it goes live
ok i think that you would see this is not all that similar to fun with set theory
the puzzle is pending approval right now if you would like to give it a try.
Nah no need, let people figure it out. Perhaps add a tag for Physics, Electrical or something like that. Ooh, and string parsing
puzzle is in "ready"

Ok fair enough, you've put some thought into it so I'm fine with that.
Having solved your puzzle I'd say it's right in the middle of easy and medium, for whatever that's worth :D

Edit : just an idea. Maybe you could add cases where the circuits are improperly designed and push the difficulty to medium. In case of an error the user has to output the wrong part, for example " [ ( A [ B C ) ) ]" would output "short-circuit : [ B C )", something like that.

I’ll leave those puzzles to JBM haha I’ve already started on making a version of this puzzle using a map requiring the code to construct the circuit itself. Also that isn’t really what a short circuit would imply but that’s not within the scope of the puzzle. I could add some tougher test cases and make it medium but I don’t really see much of a need to do so. This isn’t too complicated for easy IMO
just realized you were the second to approve that puzzle haha. I think I'll shoot him a message saying that I used his monospace style in my puzzle, I am certain he won't mind.
Also what about a puzzle taking the same input string but producing a diagram like your one for the example? could be interesting :-)

Condensed form could look (something) like
+--C--+
+--A--+
+-A-B-+
+-bat-+
(some work required here)

that would be cool but the amount of logic i would need to specify to the user might be an issue. Also check out https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/advanced-tree
its kind of like what you are describing.

Yes it's similar, and it was kind of a pain to do ^^
I'd rather stick with the recursive parsing.

Yeah i think id rather do the build a circuit from an input graph first and maybe after that there could be an ASCII art puzzle like what youre describing. If you would want to go ahead and make that one youre more than welcome to. I get what it's like getting a good idea inspired by someone elses contribution and then being like "damn, I can't really just make that, it'd be pretty obvious why im doing it", go right ahead honestly. It'd be a completely different puzzle anyway. (I think?)
also, i think i'll change the puzzle to "ready" after a few more days, don't want to jump the gun or anything and theres really not any rush
puzzle is in "ready" mode
